instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.A1297: What is A1297? A1297 is a model number for a 17 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Early 2009, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011 with EMC 2272, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2390, 820-2610, 820-2849, 820-2914..

threads.title: How it is called or where can I get this connector?
threads.message: The connector is from the mic, the cable and microphone are perfect but the connector is broken.

threads.title: How it is called or where can I get this connector?
threads.message:
I have some of these connectors lying here. You can harvest some of your donor boards.

I set my hot air station as high as it will go and heat the board from the other side. It takes about 40sec for my Aoyue to melt the solder of the other side of the board!

threads.title: How it is called or where can I get this connector?
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Crizz, post: 2233"]I have some of these connectors lying here. You can harvest some of your donor boards.

I set my hot air station as high as it will go and heat the board from the other side. It takes about 40sec for my Aoyue to melt the solder of the other side of the board!
[/QUOTE]

I mean the male one I have a few microphone cables with that problem.
Thank you Crizz for your prompt reply
